Legal_Issue: Whether Hyundai infringed ABB's patents (772 and 781) for medium voltage gas-insulated switchgear assemblies
Evidence_Assessment: Expert testimonies, prior art analysis, technical details of GIS assemblies
Decision_Outcome: No infringement; both patents declared invalid
Burden_of_Proof: On ABB to prove unauthorized use of patented technology
Credibility_Factor: Expert testimonies and technical evidence evaluated by court
Legal_Rule: Patent infringement requires proof of unauthorized use of patented technology. Validity depends on novelty, non-obviousness, and proper claim construction
Standard_of_Review: Legal principles of patent law including novelty and non-obviousness
Procedural_Issue: Claim construction and validity challenges during trial
Grounds_for_Claim: ABB alleged Hyundai sold GIS assemblies infringing patents 772 and 781
Outcome_on_Merits: In favor of Hyundai; ABB's claims dismissed
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Court conducted evaluation of technical evidence and legal arguments fairly
Key_Evidence_Considered: Prior art showing inspection windows were known; design differences in Hyundai's GIS lacking claimed features
Legal_Framework: Patent Act provisions on infringement and validity
Legal_Rule_Source: Statutory patent law and case law on claim construction
Defendant_Response: Hyundai contested validity of patents and denied infringement
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, expert testimony, technical specifications
Remedy_Sought: Invalidation of patents by Hyundai via counterclaim
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Obviousness and lack of inventive step
Jurisdiction: Federal Court (assuming based on patent jurisdiction)
Governing_Rule: Patent infringement and validity rules under U.S. law
